Coming up, it's the largest payout yet in any Catholic Church sex abuse case - $660 million.
Over the weekend, the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles agreed to settle with more than 500 alleged victims of sexual abuse by clergy, ending five years of negotiations.
That's more than $1 million per plaintiff.
In a few minutes we'll talk with one of those victims.
But first, for the latest in the settlement, we're joined by Rob Schmitz from member station KQED.
Welcome to the program.
Thanks.
Rob, what's been the reaction to this huge settlement from the victims?
Well, the victims that I've spoken with - one in particular this weekend since the news was released, and he was actually getting prepared for trial today.
And for the last month, he's been taking depositions and he's kind of had to remember a lot of the abuse that he suffered.
And so for him it was kind of a - he had conflicting feelings about it.
I think he was relieved, but at the same time I think he was disappointed that the church waited this long to settle.
But are there critics among the victims, people who wanted to go to trial to have this out in the open?
Definitely, because I think that a trial would mean that Cardinal Roger Mahony would have taken the stand, that a lot of the personnel files would have been released.
The personnel files now are going to be released.
However, the caveat is that a private judge is going to mediate any objections from individual priests.
So that might take a while and a lot of files might not see the light of day.
But we may find out that there were some cover-ups from those papers, correct?
That's correct.

I mean the lawyers that I've talked to for the plaintiffs that have seen these files say that they implicate Roger Mahony - Cardinal Roger Mahony - as a big member of this cover-up and someone who was shuffling priests from parish to parish.
What about Catholic parishioners in L.A.? Sunday mass must have been quite a scene.
Yes.
A lot of parishioners are, I think, relieved.
A lot of parishioners are also asking why the church did wait so long.
Some parishioners are wondering if the church is going to be able to afford this very weighty settlement.
And that's a big question.
So how is the Archdiocese going to raise that money?
Well, according to the Los Angeles Times, the Archdiocese has around 1,600 properties and they're worth about $4 billion.
So you know, $660 million - and I should mention that only about 250 million of that is actually going to be paid in cash by the church.
The rest of it is going to be by insurers.
I think the Archdiocese is probably going - it's not going to bring the Archdiocese to its financial knees.
It will be able to continue its mission, keep its schools and churches running.
There are other sex abuse cases waiting to be settled or tried.
How does this settlement affect those cases?
Well, it seems that with each settlement that we've seen over the years, the figure seems to get larger per victim.
And I think that right now the next big one is going to be San Diego.
And San Diego has already filed for bankruptcy protection.
And they have until the end of August to come to an agreement before trials begin.
So I think what we're going to see is probably larger settlements per victim and bigger damages to the diocese that are involved.
Rob Schmitz from member station KQED.
Thank you very much.
Thank you.

There's been one very dominant player in men's tennis lately and for a change his name is not Roger or Rafa.
It's the Serbian, Novak Djokovic, who's been king of the court, winning all 41 of his matches this year.
Djokovic is set to play Roger Federer tomorrow in the French Open semifinals.
If he wins, he'll tie the record John McEnroe set for most wins to begin a season.
He would also take tennis's number one ranking, replacing Rafael Nadal at the top.
Well, Jon Wertheim covers tennis for Sports Illustrated.
And Jon, tell us just how good is Djokovic this year?
He's exceptionally good.
I mean, sometimes we see these streaks where empirically it doesn't necessarily reflect quality.
But here in this case, I mean he's playing at just this phenomenally high level, he's beating all the best players, he's doing it on different continents, on different surfaces.

This is really - I mean it's exactly what you said - we had this sort of embarrassment of riches where we had for five years Nadal and Federer, two of the greatest of all time, then here comes this third-party candidate who's probably putting together the best six months streak that we've ever seen.
Well, and what's going on?
Are Nadal and Federer getting worse or has Djokovic just gotten really, really good?
Yeah, I think it's a combination.
I mean, Djokovic was always number three, banging on the door, and when is he going to really infiltrate this Federer-Nadal rivalry.
And he's done so this year.
He's upgraded his fitness.
I think some of this - you're right - owes to the decline of Federer, who's now in his late 20s - old in tennis - and not coincidentally the father of twins.
The real surprise is just the ease with which Djokovic has beaten Nadal four times running now.

I mean that's really what I think has given his streak so much heft, is that he's beaten Nadal on Nadal's preferred surface.

And it's hard especially in tennis, 'cause you go to these players' lounges and the only thing they have to eat half the time is pasta and carbs.
So you know, I'm not sure how easy it is to be gluten-free, but he really says, look, that's been the key to my successes here.
